sen.j: 臺與（とよ、235年頃？－没年不詳）は日本の弥生時代3世紀に『三国志 (歴史書)』、魏志倭人伝中の邪馬壹国の女王卑弥呼の親族にして、卑弥呼の跡を継いだとされる女性・壹與のことである。
sen.e: Toyo (臺與; c. 235 - year of death unknown), also written as 壹與, was a girl who was said to have succeeded Himiko as her relative in the 3rd century of the Yayoi period (c. 250 bc – c. ad 250; Yayoi derives from the name of district in Tokyo where the pottery representing this period unearthed) in Japan; Himiko was a queen of Yamataikoku (the largest chiefdom in Japan c. 250 governed by a female shaman named Himiko), who was in Gishiwajinden (Worenchuan [account of the Wa people] section of the volume Records of Wei [history of Cao Wei Kingdom; 220 - 265 in China]) in "Sanguo Zhi (a history book)" (Records of the Three Kingdoms; a historical record on the Three Kingdoms of Wei, Shu and Wu in ancient China).

Toyo (臺與; c. 235 - year of death unknown), also written as 壹與, was a girl who was said to have succeeded Himiko as her relative in the 3rd century of the Yayoi period (c. 250 bc – c. ad 250; Yayoi derives from the name of district in Tokyo where the pottery representing this period unearthed) in Japan; Himiko was a queen of Yamataikoku (the largest chiefdom in Japan c. 250 governed by a female shaman named Himiko), who was in Gishiwajinden (Worenchuan [account of the Wa people] section of the volume Records of Wei [history of Cao Wei Kingdom; 220 - 265 in China]) in "Sanguo Zhi (a history book)" (Records of the Three Kingdoms; a historical record on the Three Kingdoms of Wei, Shu and Wu in ancient China).

Toyo (臺與; c. 235 - year of death unknown), also written as 壹與, was a woman who was said to have succeeded Himiko as her relative in the 3rd century of the Yayoi period (c. 250 BC – c. 250 AD; Yayoi derives from the name of district in Tokyo where the pottery representing this period unearthed) in Japan; Himiko was a queen of Yamataikoku (the largest chiefdom in Japan c. 250 governed by a female shaman named Himiko), who was in Gishiwajinden (Worenchuan [account of the Wa people] section of the volume Records of Wei [history of Cao Wei Kingdom; 220 - 265 in China]) in "Sanguo Zhi (a history book)" (Records of the Three Kingdoms; a historical record on the Three Kingdoms of Wei, Shu and Wu in ancient China).

sen.j: 魏志倭人伝中では「壹與」であるが、後代の書である『梁書』『北史』では「臺與」と記述されている。
sen.e: In the Gishiwajinden, her name was written as '壹與' but it was written as '臺與' in "Book of the Liang Dynasty" and in "History of Northern Dynasties," both of which were issued in later days.
In the Gishiwajinden, her name was written as '壹與' but it was written as '臺與' in "Book of the Liang Dynasty" and in "History of Northern Dynasties," both of which were issued in later days.
In the Gishiwajinden, her name was written as '壹與' but it was written as '臺與' in "Book of the Liang Dynasty" and in "History of Northern Dynasties," both of which were issued in later days.

sen.j: 「台与」は「臺與」の代用。
sen.e: '台与' is the substitute of '臺與'.
'台与' is the substitute of '臺與'.
'台与' is the substitute of '臺與'.

sen.j: 臺與の表記・読みについては異説が多く詳細は後記。
sen.e: Since how to write and read 臺與 are quite controversial matters, they will be discussed later.
Since how to write and read 臺與 are quite controversial matters, they will be discussed later.
Since the Chinese characters and pronunciation of Toyo are quite controversial matters, they will be discussed later.

sen.j: 表記・読み
sen.e: How to write and read her name
How to write and read her name
The Chinese characters and pronunciation of her name

sen.j: 『三国志』魏書東夷傳の倭人之条、（通称魏志倭人伝、陳寿編纂、3世紀・晋代）では2写本系統とも「壹與」と記載されている。
sen.e: At Worenchuan section (Account of the Wa People section) in the book called Weizhi Dongyi zhuan (Records of Wei Concerning Eastern Barbarians) among "Sanguo Zhi" (History of the Three Kingdoms), (the popular name of this section is Gishiwajinden, compiled by Shou CHEN, 3rd century, Jin period) her name was written as '壹與' in both manuscript printing lines.

At Worenchuan section (Account of the Wa People section) in the book called Weizhi Dongyi zhuan (Records of Wei Concerning Eastern Barbarians) among "Sanguo Zhi" (History of the Three Kingdoms), (the popular name of this section is Gishiwajinden, compiled by Shou CHEN, 3rd century, Jin period) her name was written as '壹與' in both manuscript printing lines.

At Worenchuan section (Account of the Wa People section) in the book called Weizhi Dongyi zhuan (Records of Wei Concerning Eastern Barbarians) among "Sanguo Zhi" (History of the Three Kingdoms), (the popular name of this section is Gishiwajinden, compiled by Shou CHEN, 3rd century, Jin period) her name was written as '壹與' in both manuscript printing lines.

sen.j: 発音は、い（ゐ）よ＝壹與？。
sen.e: The pronunciation was I(or Wi)yo = 壹與?
sen.cmt: （ゐ）をヘボン式で表記すると"I" となりますが、（い）と区別がつきませんので（ゐ）を "Wi" と表記しました。
sen.e: The pronunciation was I(or Wi)yo = 壹與?
The pronunciation could be Iyo for the characters 壹與.

sen.j: 『梁書』諸夷伝 倭（姚思廉編纂、636年・唐代）、『北史』東夷伝（李延寿編纂・唐代）などに記述。
sen.e: However her name was written as '臺與' both at the Account of Wa (ancient Japan) section in the volume of Various Barbarians of "Liang shu" (History of the Liang) (compiled by Yao Silian, ad 636, Tang period), and at the Account of Eastern Barbarians chapter of "Bei shi"(History of the Northern Dynasties) (compiled by Li Yanshou, Tang period).
sen.cmt: 訳文の冒頭は原文の省略部分を訳出したものです。
sen.e: However her name was written as '臺與' both at the Account of Wa (ancient Japan) section in the volume of Various Barbarians of "Liang shu" (History of the Liang) (compiled by Yao Silian, ad 636, Tang period), and at the Account of Eastern Barbarians chapter of "Bei shi"(History of the Northern Dynasties) (compiled by Li Yanshou, Tang period).

Her name was written as '臺與' both in the Account of Wa (ancient Japan) section in the volume of Various Barbarians of "Liang shu" (History of the Liang) (compiled by Yao Silian, ad 636, Tang period), and in the Account of Eastern Barbarians chapter of "Bei shi"(History of the Northern Dynasties) (compiled by Li Yanshou, Tang period).

sen.j: 発音に関する議論
sen.e: Arguments on the pronunciation
Controversy on the pronunciation
sen.cmt: 語彙をより適切と思われるものに変更しました。
sen.e: Controversy on the pronunciation

sen.j: 「臺與」を「とよ」と読むのが通説となっているが、これには議論がある。
sen.e: It is a popular argument that '臺與' should be pronounced as 'Toyo,' but there are other judgments.
It is a popular argument that '臺與' should be pronounced as 'Toyo,' but there are other judgments.
According to common belief '臺與' should be pronounced as 'Toyo,' but there are other theories.

sen.j: 「台」であれば、「と」と読めるということに異論は無いようである。
sen.e: If instead of '臺,' the character '台' had been used, then there would seem to exist no objection to read it as 'To'.
sen.cmt: 訳文の冒頭は原文の省略部分を訳出したものです。
sen.e: If instead of '臺,' the character '台' had been used, then there would seem to exist no objection to read it as 'To'.
If the character '台' had been used instead of '臺,' then there would seem to be no objection to pronounce it as 'To'.

sen.j: しかし、「臺」と「台」は異なる文字である。
sen.e: However, '臺' and '台' are different characters.
However, '臺' and '台' are different characters.
However, '臺' and '台' are different characters.

sen.j: 「臺」を「と」と読む根拠は、例えば藤堂明保『国語音韻論』に、「魏志倭人伝で、『ヤマト』を『邪馬臺』と書いてあるのは有名な事実である」と記載されていることに求められているが、これはすなわち「邪馬臺ヤマト」という当時の通説に基づいた記述に過ぎないことが読み取れると言う指摘がある。
sen.e: A ground to read '臺' as 'To' is, for example, based on the description in "Chinese Phonology" written by Akiyasu TODO, in which he said 'It is a famous fact that "Yamato" was written as "邪馬臺" in the Gishiwajinden.', but it is pointed out that his description seemed to be merely depending on the then prevailing idea of reading '邪馬臺' as 'Yamato'.
sen.cmt: 原文には「藤堂明保『国語音韻論』に、」とあります。文脈から考えても、調査からもこの書は『国語音韻論』ではなく、『中国語音韻論』(1957年)ISBN 4-332-83001-6と考えられます。脱字と判断し『中国語音韻論』として訳しました。
sen.e: A ground to read '臺' as 'To' is, for example, based on the description in "Chinese Phonology" written by Akiyasu TODO, in which he said 'It is a famous fact that "Yamato" was written as "邪馬臺" in the Gishiwajinden.', but it is pointed out that his description seemed to be merely depending on the then prevailing idea of reading '邪馬臺' as 'Yamato'.

A ground to read '臺' as 'To' is, for example, based on the description in "Chinese Phonology" written by Akiyasu TODO, in which he said 'It is a famous fact that "Yamato" was written as "邪馬臺" in the Gishiwajinden.', but it is pointed out that his description seemed to be merely depending on the then prevailing idea of reading '邪馬臺' as 'Yamato'.

sen.j: もしこの意見が妥当なら、漢和辞典の記載を根拠に「『邪馬臺』はヤマトと読める、『臺與』はトヨと読める」と言ったところで、大元にある通説の同義反復に過ぎないことになるが、「臺」の発音に関する中国語音韻論による議論はこの意見とは無関係である。
sen.e: If this objection against him is reasonable, it is also reasonable to point out the fact that just to say '"邪馬臺" can be read as Yamato, "臺與" can be read as Toyo' based on the contents of Chinese-Japanese character dictionaries is nothing but a mere synonymous repetition depending on the popular idea as the ground; but to discuss the pronunciation of '臺' based on Chinese phonetics has nothing to do with this argument.

If this objection against him is reasonable, it is also reasonable to point out the fact that just to say '"邪馬臺" can be read as Yamato, "臺與" can be read as Toyo' based on the contents of Chinese-Japanese character dictionaries is nothing but a mere synonymous repetition depending on the popular idea as the ground; but to discuss the pronunciation of '臺' based on Chinese phonetics has nothing to do with this argument.

If this objection against him is reasonable, it is also reasonable to point out the fact that just to say '"邪馬臺" can be read as Yamato, "臺與" can be read as Toyo' based on the contents of Chinese-Japanese character dictionaries is nothing but a mere synonymous repetition depending on the popular idea as the ground; but to discuss the pronunciation of '臺' based on Chinese phonetics has nothing to do with this argument.

sen.j: 邪馬臺の発音をヤマドとする説がある。
sen.e: There also is an argument that 邪馬臺 should be read as Yamado.
There is also a theory that 邪馬臺 should be pronounced as Yamado.
There is also a theory that 邪馬臺 should be pronounced as Yamado.

sen.j: 魏志の編纂が後者二書に比べ大きく先行している。
sen.e: The Records of Wei had been compiled long before the other two history books.
The Records of Wei had been compiled long before the other two history books.
The Records of Wei had been compiled long before the other two history books.

sen.j: 三書はいずれも『魏略』を元にしていると考えられる。
sen.e: The contents of the three history books presumably came from "Weilue"(Brief Account of the Wei Dynasty).
The contents of the three history books presumably came from "Weilue"(Brief Account of the Wei Dynasty).
The contents of the three history books presumably came from "Weilue"(Brief Account of the Wei Dynasty).

sen.j: 『魏略』には他の書に引用された逸文が残っているが、そこには該当部分は存在しないため正確にはどう書いてあったのか不明である。
sen.e: The "Weilue" was lost but some of its contents were quoted on other books; however since no corresponding part about her name remains, so how her name was exactly written is unknown.
The "Weilue" was lost but some of its contents were quoted on other books; however since no corresponding part about her name remains, so how her name was exactly written is unknown.
The "Weilue" was lost but some of its contents were quoted on other books; however since no corresponding part about her name remains, so how her name was exactly written is unknown.

sen.j: しかし、魏志以外に「壹與」の表記が見られないことから、『魏略』の元の表記は「臺與」（とよ）であろう、という推測がある（あくまで推測である）。
sen.e: Since there was no use of characters '壹與' except in "Records of Wei," there is a presumption － although it is only a presumption － that the original expression in "Weilue" might be '臺與' (Toyo).
Since there was no use of characters '壹與' except in "Records of Wei," there is a presumption － although it is only a presumption － that the original expression in "Weilue" might be '臺與' (Toyo).
Since there was no use of characters '壹與' except in "Records of Wei," there is a presumption － although it is only a presumption － that the original expression in "Weilue" might be '臺與' (Toyo).

sen.j: これに基づき、『古事記』『日本書紀』に登場する「豊～」という表記や北九州の「豊の国」と言う古名は、「臺與」に由来するのではないかという説がある。
sen.e: Based on this idea, there comes a theory that the words '豊 ---; Toyo ---' found in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), as well as '豊の国; Toyo Country' － the ancient name of northern Kyushu － might derive from '臺與; Toyo'.
sen.cmt: 訳文最後の’’は単語なのでピリオドは外に出してあります。
sen.e: Based on this idea, there comes a theory that the words '豊 ---; Toyo ---' found in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), as well as '豊の国; Toyo Country' － the ancient name of northern Kyushu － might derive from '臺與; Toyo'.

Based on this idea, there comes a theory that the words '豊 ---; Toyo ---' found in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), as well as '豊の国; Toyo Country' － the ancient name of northern Kyushu － might derive from '臺與; Toyo'.

sen.j: 事跡
sen.e: Achievements
Achievements
Achievements

sen.j: 魏志倭人伝によると、以下とされる。
sen.e: The description of Gishiwajinden says, `After the death of Queen Himiko, a male king took the throne.
The description of Gishiwajinden says, `After the death of Queen Himiko, a male king took the throne.
The description of Gishiwajinden says as follows:
sen.cmt: 文末の」とされる。をこちらのまとめ、「」内は別に分けました。一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 「女王卑弥呼が死ぬと男子の王が立てられた。」
sen.e: After the death of Queen Himiko, a male king took the throne.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処前列から分離しました。原文にカギ括弧を、訳文にクォーテーションをつけました。

sen.j: 「邪馬壹國の人々はこれに服さず、内乱状態になり1000人が死んだ。」
sen.e: People in Yamataikoku [8] would not obey him and due to the following civil war, one thousand people were slain.
People in Yamataikoku would not obey him and due to the following civil war, one thousand people were slain.
People in Yamataikoku would not obey him and due to the following civil war, one thousand people were slain.'
sen.cmt: 原文にカギ括弧を、訳文にクォーテーションをつけました。

sen.j: 「このため再び女王が立てられることになり、卑弥呼の親族の13歳の少女の壹與が王となり、国は治まった。」
sen.e: To settle the situation, a queen was to be made, and a relative of Himiko named Iyo, a girl of thirteen, took the throne and order was restored.
To settle the situation, a queen was to be made, and a relative of Himiko named Iyo, a girl of thirteen, took the throne and order was restored.
To settle the situation, it was decided that a queen would be required again, and a thirteen-year-old girl called Iyo, a relative of Himiko, took the throne and order was restored.'
sen.cmt: a girl of thirteen→a thirteen-year-old girl原文にカギ括弧を、訳文にクォーテーションをつけました。

sen.j: 「正始8年（248年）に邪馬壹國と狗奴国間の紛争の報告を受けて倭に派遣された帯方郡の塞曹掾史張政は、檄文をもって壹與を諭した。」
sen.e: Upon a receipt of report informing a dispute between Yamataikoku and Kunukoku in 248 (Zhengshi 8), Chang Cheng, an acting Secretary of the Border Guard, was dispatched from Daifang Commandery [9], and he persuaded Iyo with a letter of proclamation advising reconciliation.
sen.cmt: http://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%AD%A3%E5%A7%8B_(%E9%AD%8F)などで「正始8年」は247年とするものが多数ですが、原文に従い248年としました。
sen.e: Upon a receipt of report informing a dispute between Yamataikoku and Kunukoku in 248 (Zhengshi 8), Chang Cheng, an acting Secretary of the Border Guard, was dispatched from Daifang Commandery, and he persuaded Iyo with a letter of proclamation advising reconciliation.'
sen.cmt: 引用文の最後に「'」を追加しました。
sen.e: Upon a receipt of report informing a dispute between Yamataikoku and Kunukoku in 248 (Zhengshi 8), Chang Cheng, an acting Secretary of the Border Guard, was dispatched from Daifang Commandery, and he persuaded Iyo with a letter of proclamation advising reconciliation.'
sen.cmt: 原文にカギ括弧を、訳文にクォーテーションをつけました。

sen.j: このことから、卑弥呼の死と壹與の王位継承とは、張政が倭に渡った248年からそれ程年月が経っていないと思われる。
sen.e: These descriptions connoted that not so many years had elapsed after Himiko's death and subsequent Iyo's success of the throne until Chang Cheng's arrival in Wa in 248.
These descriptions connoted that not so many years had elapsed after Himiko's death and subsequent Iyo's success of the throne until Chang Cheng's arrival in Wa in 248.
These descriptions connoted that not so many years had elapsed after Himiko's death and subsequent Iyo's success of the throne until Chang Cheng's arrival in Wa in 248.

sen.j: その後、「壹與は掖邪狗ら20人に張政の帰還を送らせ、掖邪狗らは魏の都に上り、男女の生口30人と白珠5000孔、青大句珠2枚、異文の雑錦20匹を貢いだ。」
sen.e: Afterwards, Gishiwajinden goes on saying, 'Iyo sent Yasuku with twenty other men to accompany Chang CHENG home; they went up to the capital of Wei and paid tribute of thirty male and female slaves, five thousand pieces of white gem, two pieces of carved jade, as well as twenty bolts of assorted brocade with novel designs.

Afterwards, Gishiwajinden goes on saying, 'Iyo sent Yasuku with twenty other men to accompany Chang CHENG home; they went up to the capital of Wei and paid tribute of thirty male and female slaves, five thousand pieces of white gem, two pieces of carved jade, as well as twenty bolts of assorted brocade with novel designs.'
sen.cmt: 引用文の最後に「'」を追加しました。
sen.e: Afterwards, Gishiwajinden goes on saying, 'Iyo sent Yasuku with twenty other men to accompany Chang CHENG home; they went up to the capital of Wei and paid tribute of thirty male and female slaves, five thousand pieces of white gem, two pieces of carved jade, as well as twenty bolts of assorted brocade with novel designs.'

sen.j: 『日本書紀』の神功紀に引用される『晋書』起居註に泰始 (晋)2年（266年）に倭の女王の使者が朝貢したとの記述があり、この女王は台与と考えられている。
sen.e: According to Qijuzhu (Court Diaries) of "Jin shu"(History of the Jin Dynasty) which was quoted in the Jingu section of "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), an emissary of the Queen of Wa brought tribute to Jin in 266 (Taishi 2 = Jin 2); it is a popular idea that this queen might be Toyo.

According to Qijuzhu (Court Diaries) of "Jin shu"(History of the Jin Dynasty) which was quoted in the Jingu section of "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), an emissary of the Queen of Wa brought tribute to Jin in 266 (Taishi 2 = Jin 2); it is a popular idea that this queen might be Toyo.

According to Qijuzhu (Court Diaries) of "Jin shu"(History of the Jin Dynasty) which was quoted in the Jingu section of "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), an emissary of the Queen of Wa brought tribute to Jin in 266 (Taishi 2 = Jin 2); it is a popular idea that this queen might be Toyo.

sen.j: この年は、中国では曹操に始まる魏王朝の曹一族に世継ぎができなかったため、親族の幼少の皇帝が3代続いた時代だった。
sen.e: This 266 was the year in China, when overthrowing the Emperor by a peaceful transfer of power by the Sima family, the Emperor's maternal relative, was on the way, － which would establish the Jin Dynasty － after three successive infant Emperors from the relatives due to the absence of heirs from direct family line of the Wei Dynasty originated by Cao Cao.

This 266 was the year in China, when overthrowing the Emperor by a peaceful transfer of power by the Sima family, the Emperor's maternal relative, was on the way, － which would establish the Jin Dynasty － after three successive infant Emperors from the relatives due to the absence of heirs from direct family line of the Wei Dynasty originated by Cao Cao.
This was a year when China had three successive infant Emperors from the relatives due to the absence of heirs from direct line of the Cao family of the Wei Dynasty originating with Cao Cao.
sen.cmt: 2 文に分けて少し書き換えました。一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 外戚の司馬氏が建てた晋に禅譲革命が行われてゆく途上の年であった。
sen.e: Also it was in the middle of the peaceful transfer of power to the Jin Dynasty established by the Shima clan, the Emperor's maternal relative.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: この朝貢の記録を最後に中国の史書から邪馬台国や倭に関する記録が途絶え、次に現れるのは150年の後の義熙9年（413年）の倭王讃の朝貢（倭の五王）である。
sen.e: After the account of this tribute, there had been no description about either Yamataikoku or Wa in the Chinese history books until in 413 (Yixi 9), 150 years later, when there appeared an account of tribute by San, a King of Wa (one of the Five Kings of Wa).

After the account of this tribute, there had been no description about either Yamataikoku or Wa in the Chinese history books until in 413 (Yixi 9), 150 years later, when there appeared an account of tribute by San, a King of Wa (one of the Five Kings of Wa).

After the account of this tribute, there had been no description about either Yamataikoku or Wa in the Chinese history books until in 413 (Yixi 9), 150 years later, when there appeared an account of tribute by San, a King of Wa (one of the Five Kings of Wa).

sen.j: 台与と後のヤマト王権との関係は諸説あってはっきりしない。
sen.e: The connection between Toyo and Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereignty) of later days still remains vague, although there have been numerous arguments.
The connection between Toyo and Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereignty) of later days still remains vague, although there have been numerous arguments.

sen.e: The discussions aiming to identify Toyo are not ongoing among scholars now due to the following reasons.

sen.j: 2人のアマテラス説
sen.e: Two different Amaterasu (the Sun Goddess) theory
Two different Amaterasu (the Sun Goddess) theory
The theory of two different Amaterasu (the Sun Goddess)

sen.j: 一説には、「日本神話の岩戸隠れの前後のアマテラスは別の人物であり、それぞれ卑弥呼と台与である」として「アマテラスを誰に比定するか」という議論とともに考えようとするものがある。
sen.e: According to one theory, 'The persons called Amaterasu who existed before and after the incident of Iwato-gakure (the hiding of Amaterasu Omikami, the sun goddess, in the heavenly rock cave) were different individuals, Himiko and Toyo respectively.'; therefore, this theory argues that it is proper to discuss the matter －Who was Toyo？－ together with the discussion of 'Who should be identified as Amaterasu?'.

According to one theory, 'The persons called Amaterasu who existed before and after the incident of Iwato-gakure (the hiding of Amaterasu Omikami, the sun goddess, in the heavenly rock cave) were different individuals, Himiko and Toyo respectively.'; therefore, this theory argues that it is proper to discuss the matter －Who was Toyo？－ together with the discussion of 'Who should be identified as Amaterasu?'.

According to one theory, 'The persons called Amaterasu who existed before and after the incident of Iwato-gakure (the hiding of Amaterasu Omikami, the sun goddess, in the heavenly rock cave) were different individuals, Himiko and Toyo respectively.'; therefore, this theory argues that it is proper to discuss the matter －Who was Toyo？－ together with the discussion of 'Who should be identified as Amaterasu?'.

sen.j: 卑弥呼をアマテラスに比定する場合に多くみられ、卑弥呼没年前後の皆既日食によって岩戸隠れの故事を説明しようとする説である。
sen.e: This thinking is largely accepted among who identify Himiko as Amaterasu, and this identification leads to a hypothesis to explain the historical incident of Iwato-gakure by the total eclipse of the sun, which happened around the death of Himiko.

This thinking is largely accepted among who identify Himiko as Amaterasu, and this identification leads to a hypothesis to explain the historical incident of Iwato-gakure by the total eclipse of the sun, which happened around the death of Himiko.

This thinking is largely accepted among who identify Himiko as Amaterasu, and this identification leads to a hypothesis to explain the historical incident of Iwato-gakure by the total eclipse of the sun, which happened around the death of Himiko.

sen.j: 万幡豊秋津師比売説
sen.e: Yorozuhatatoyoakitu-hime (Princess Yorozuhatatoyoakitu-hime) theory
Yorozuhatatoyoakitu-hime (Princess Yorozuhatatoyoakitu-hime) theory
The theory of Toyo as Yorozuhatatoyoakitu-hime

sen.j: 卑弥呼をアマテラスに比定する場合の説。
sen.e: This hypothesis is valid in case Himiko is identified as Amaterasu.
This hypothesis is valid in case Himiko is identified as Amaterasu.
This hypothesis is valid in case Himiko is identified as Amaterasu.

sen.j: 栲幡千千姫命（ヨロヅハタトヨアキツシヒメ）は高御産巣日神（タカミムスビ）の娘。
sen.e: Yorozuhatatoyoakitu-hime was a daughter of Takamimusubi no kami (Deity Takamimusubi no kami).
sen.cmt: 原文は「栲幡千千姫命（ヨロヅハタトヨアキツシヒメ）は高御産巣日神（タカミムスビ）の娘。」となっています。「栲幡千千姫命」は前列の「万幡豊秋津師比売」の誤植と思います。訳文には漢字を用いませんので支障ありませんが、一応お知らせします。 また原文の「高御産巣日神」は「（タカミムスビ）」となっていますが、（ノカミ）が脱字していると判断し訳しました。
sen.e: Yorozuhatatoyoakitu-hime was a daughter of Takamimusubi no kami (Deity Takamimusubi no kami).
Yorozuhatatoyoakitu-hime was a daughter of Takamimusubi no kami (Deity Takamimusubi no kami).

sen.j: アマテラスの息子アメノオシホミミと結婚し、アメノホアカリとニニギの母となった。
sen.e: Yorozuhatatoyoakitu-hime married Amenooshihomimi, a son of Amaterasu, and became the mother of Amenohoakari and Ninigi.
Yorozuhatatoyoakitu-hime married Amenooshihomimi, a son of Amaterasu, and became the mother of Amenohoakari and Ninigi.
Yorozuhatatoyoakitu-hime married Amenooshihomimi, a son of Amaterasu, and became the mother of Amenohoakari and Ninigi.

sen.j: アマテラスの極めて近い親族で名前の中に「トヨ」の文字がある彼女を臺與に比定する説で、安本美典が『新版・卑弥呼の謎』（講談社現代新書）で述べている。
sen.e: This theory is to identify Toyo as Yorozuhatatoyoakitu-hime, because she was the person who was a very close relative of Amaterasu and had the character of 'Toyo' in her name; this was the argument Biten YASUMOTO wrote in his "The mystery of Himiko; New Edition"(Kodansha new book).

This theory is to identify Toyo as Yorozuhatatoyoakitu-hime, because she was the person who was a very close relative of Amaterasu and had the character of 'Toyo' in her name; this was the argument Biten YASUMOTO wrote in his "The mystery of Himiko; New Edition"(Kodansha new book).

This theory is to identify Toyo as Yorozuhatatoyoakitu-hime, because she was the person who was a very close relative of Amaterasu and had the character of 'Toyo' in her name; this was the argument Biten YASUMOTO wrote in his "The mystery of Himiko; New Edition"(Kodansha new book).

sen.j: 彼女はアマテラスが主祭神である伊勢神宮の内宮の相殿神の一人であり、安本はそれをこの説の根拠のひとつとしている。
sen.e: She is one of Aidonoshin (deities enshrined together) at Naiku (Inner shrine) of Ise-jingu Shrine where Amaterasu is the main enshrined deity, which is one of the grounds of his hypothesis.
She is one of Aidonoshin (deities enshrined together) at Naiku (Inner shrine) of Ise-jingu Shrine where Amaterasu is the main enshrined deity, which is one of the grounds of his hypothesis.
She is one of Aidonoshin (deities enshrined together) at Naiku (Inner shrine) of Ise-jingu Shrine where Amaterasu is the main enshrined deity, which is one of the grounds of his hypothesis.

sen.j: 天豊姫命説
sen.e: Amatoyo-hime no mikoto (HH Princess Amatoyo-hime no mikoto) theory
Amatoyo-hime no mikoto (HH Princess Amatoyo-hime no mikoto) theory
The theory of Toyo as Amatoyo-hime no mikoto
sen.cmt: HHは必要ないと思います。

sen.j: 尾張氏、海部氏の祖彦火明、七世孫建諸隅命の子、天豊姫を臺與とする説。
sen.e: This hypothesis identifies Toyo as Amatoyo-hime who was a child of Takemorozumi no mikoto (HH Takemorozumi no mikoto); he was the seventh grandchild of Hikohoakari who was the ancestor of Owari clan and Amabe clan.

This hypothesis identifies Toyo as Amatoyo-hime who was a child of Takemorozumi no mikoto (HH Takemorozumi no mikoto); he was the seventh grandchild of Hikohoakari who was the ancestor of Owari clan and Amabe clan.
This hypothesis identifies Toyo as Amatoyo-hime, a child of Takemorozumi no mikoto who was the seventh grandchild of Hikohoakari, the ancestor of Owari clan and Amabe clan.
sen.cmt: HHは必要ないと思います。

sen.j: この人の二世代前に卑弥呼と思われる、日女命がある。
sen.e: Two generations before this person, Amatoyo-hime, there existed 日女命 (reads as HH Hime no mikoto?) who was presumed to be Himiko.
Two generations before this person, Amatoyo-hime, there existed 日女命 (reads as HH Hime no mikoto?) who was presumed to be Himiko.
Two generations before Amatoyo-hime, there existed 日女命 (probably reads as Hime no mikoto) who was presumed to be Himiko.
sen.cmt: HHは必要ないと思います。

sen.j: 豊鍬入姫命説
sen.e: Toyosuki iri-bime no mikoto (HH Princess Toyosuki iri-bime no mikoto) theory
Toyosuki iri-bime no mikoto (HH Princess Toyosuki iri-bime no mikoto) theory
The theory of Toyo as Toyosuki iri-bime no mikoto
sen.cmt: HHは必要ないと思います。

sen.j: 崇神天皇の皇女である豊鍬入姫命に比定する説である。
sen.e: This hypothesis is to identify Toyo as Toyosuki iri-bime no mikoto who was a princess of Emperor Sujin.
This hypothesis is to identify Toyo as Toyosuki iri-bime no mikoto who was a princess of Emperor Sujin.
This hypothesis is to identify Toyo as Toyosuki iri-bime no mikoto who was a princess of Emperor Sujin.

sen.j: 天皇の命で天照大神を祭った初代斎宮が臺與に相当するという説。
sen.e: Another theory is to identify Toyo as the first Saigu (the ancient Imperial Princesses serving at the Ise shrine) who enshrined Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) by the Emperor's order.
Another theory is to identify Toyo as the first Saigu (the ancient Imperial Princesses serving at the Ise shrine) who enshrined Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) by the Emperor's order.
Another theory is to identify Toyo as the first Saigu (the ancient Imperial Princesses serving at the Ise shrine) who enshrined Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) by the Emperor's order.

sen.j: 卑弥呼を倭迹迹日百襲媛命とする場合にみられる。
sen.e: This is valid in case Himiko is identified as Yamatototohimomoso-hime no mikoto (HH Princess Yamatototohimomoso-hime no mikoto).
This is valid in case Himiko is identified as Yamatototohimomoso-hime no mikoto (HH Princess Yamatototohimomoso-hime no mikoto).
This is only valid in case Himiko is identified as Yamatototohimomoso-hime no mikoto.
sen.cmt: HHは必要ないと思います。

sen.j: 比定できないとする説
sen.e: Identification itself is impossible theory
Identification itself is impossible theory
Theory that states identification is impossible

sen.j: しかしながら、現在の学界では、台与を記紀の神話や系譜上の誰かに当てて邪馬台国論を理解しようとする方法論そのものに懐疑的である。
sen.e: Today's academy, however, is skeptical about the methodology itself which seeks to understand the Yamataikoku study by identifying Toyo as someone in myths or someone in genealogical chart of "Kiki" (Kojiki and Nihonshoki; "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan").

Today's academy, however, is skeptical about the methodology itself which seeks to understand the Yamataikoku study by identifying Toyo as someone in myths or someone in genealogical chart of "Kiki" (Kojiki and Nihonshoki; "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan").

Today's academy, however, is skeptical about the methodology itself which seeks to understand the Yamataikoku study by identifying Toyo as someone in myths or someone in genealogical chart of "Kiki" (Kojiki and Nihonshoki; "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan").

sen.j: なぜなら、それらは同時代史料でも良質の編纂史料でもないし、そもそも継体天皇以前の記紀の記述に、あまり正確さが期待できないためである。
sen.e: As they were not good in quality as compiled historical materials of those days, nor exactness can hardly be expected in the descriptions of Kiki, if the described matters were basically before Emperor Keitai.

As they were not good in quality as compiled historical materials of those days, nor exactness can hardly be expected in the descriptions of Kiki, if the described matters were basically before Emperor Keitai.

As they were not good in quality as compiled historical materials of those days, nor exactness can hardly be expected in the descriptions of Kiki, if the described matters were basically before Emperor Keitai.
